INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS BILL


    Order for Committee Stage read.

    Bill considered in Committee.

[Mr SPEAKER in the Chair]



2.32 p.m.

    Clause 1 ordered to stand part of the Bill.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Chairman do report progress and ask leave to sit again."

    Sir, after seven months of careful consideration, the Minister presented the Industrial Relations Bill to this Assembly on 13th January. In the space of less than one month, and on the very day that the Bill was to come up for debate on its Second Reading, the Minister in charge found it necessary to put into our hands seven pages of 50 amendments. Out of a short Bill of 37 pages, 50 amendments had to be rushed through. Sir, I use the term "rushed through", because the amendments were given to us just a few hours on the very day of the sitting at which the debate on the Bill was to take place.

Column: 222



    Had the amendments been in the nature of corrections, or alterations or sentence construction, or printing errors, or even minor oversights, then it would have been of little consequence. But as it is, Sir, the amendments consist of very important changes. In several cases, the most vital principles of the Bill are to be negatived by the amendments.

    Members of the Opposition Bench praised the Bill at the last sitting because there were signs of genuine effort to promote industrial peace, giving (as was stated by the Hon. the Prime Minister) a fair deal to the workers and, at the same time, creating conditions conducive to industrial expansion. It was, in fact, a courageous Bill, in my opinion.

    The Chairman: Order. I think the honourable Member is perhaps going a bit too far. She ought to confine herself to reasons why she thinks that the Chairman should report progress and beg leave to sit again. I think she is probably now making a Second Reading speech. She should confine herself to the motion.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Sir, I am saying all this just to show the importance of postponing the Committee stage to another day. I am giving reasons why it should be postponed, and although it might seem irrelevant now, I hope, when I tie up my reasons, to show that they are relevant and why I think the Committee stage should be postponed. We thought that the Bill was designed to prevent the reoccurrence of the mistakes of the past. But there are amendments which have been sent to us two days ago which take the essence out of this -

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Chicken!

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: - take all the essence out of this genuine effort to promote industrial peace. Sir, first the Bill was presented to us. Then before it could be passed, it has now been mutilated beyond recognition by 50 amendments. Surely it will do no harm if a little more time is spent on putting it into a shape which is acceptable to

Column: 223

all concerned, which will be of benefit to the State and all its people, and which will be a credit to the Government. I hope the Minister will agree to postpone the Committee stage to another day.

    The Chairman: Before I propose the Question, I might inform honourable Members that the Government were in time when they sent in their notices of amendments. The notices of amendments were, in fact, received in the Clerk's Office on the 8th of February. Admittedly, it did take some time for the Clerk to go through the amendments to put them into a shape acceptable to me, and it was not until the morning of 10th February that Members received their copies of the amendments. So, in so far as the Government are concerned, they were in time.

    Question proposed, "That the Chairman do report progress and ask leave to sit again."

    The Minister for Labour and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): Mr Speaker, Sir, I think this point had already been dealt with by the Prime Minister when the principles of the Bill were debated at the last sitting. Mr Speaker, Sir, I shall later be moving amendments which will clearly show to the Opposition Front Bench that the amendments do not in any way affect the main structure of the Bill. They are in respect of points of detail. And when I do so, I think I will be able to promote peace between the Opposition and ourselves.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, I received my copy of the amendments of the Minister for Labour and Law when I arrived in this Assembly about ten minutes before 2.30 p.m. I therefore had no time to become acquainted with the proposals outlined in the proposed amendments. I do not say, Sir, that the Government were out of time in submitting their amendments. But I do say that had the Opposition been aware of such amendments that were being proposed, the speeches of the Opposition on the Second Reading of the Bill might have been of a different character.

    The Prime Minister said that there was no useful purpose in referring this Bill to a Select Committee because the

Column: 224

question of principles was not involved. But I do respectfully submit, Sir, that the amendments proposed by the Minister for Labour and Law go a long way to upset the balance that was aimed at in the Bill - the balance of conflicting forces - so that there could be industrial peace. I do again say, Sir, that, because of the very nature and character of the Government amendments, more time should be given to the Opposition and to the public to become aware of their implications.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, as the Member for Cairnhill has just complained that he had no opportunity of looking at the Government amendments until 2.30 this afternoon, the Government is prepared to postpone the Committee stage to after item No. 5 on the Order Paper.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, if I had been able to read the proposed Government amendments before I made my speech on the Second Reading, I would most certainly not have spoken in the tenor in which I, in fact, had done. When we met here the day before yesterday, I thought it was an excellent Bill, a courageous Bill, because the Government was attempting to solve a very difficult problem, which is to hold the balance evenly between employees and employers in the overall interest of the State. Sir, after I have had the opportunity to look at the Government amendments and to realise their implications, I am now satisfied that the balance which the Government had so strenuously sought to preserve in the original Bill has been whittled down to the extent where one of the parties to a dispute would have lost confidence in the Bill.

    Therefore, if the primary aim and objective of this Bill is to secure industrial peace, it is, I think, imperative that both sides to the dispute should be satisfied that it is a fair and impartial Bill. At the moment, Mr Speaker, Sir, as the amendments stand, the Opposition feel that the Bill is weighted with the amendments on one side, and the balance is not held equally.

Column: 225



    The Minister has said that he has received representations from both employers and employees, and as a result of those representations he has framed these amendments. If I may say so with respect to the Minister, these amendments have been filed at the instance and at the suggestion of employees. May I ask him whether these amendments have been put to the employers to find out what their views are on them? I venture to suggest to the Minister that if these amendments had been put to the employers, they might not have readily accepted the Bill in its amended form. I therefore beg of the Minister to defer the Committee Stage, Sir, so that the employers and others who are interested in the Bill could be given adequate opportunity to examine the amendments and to see what their effect will be on industrial peace.

2.45 p.m.

    Inche Ahmad Jabri Bin Mohammad Akib (Southern Islands)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, at the last sitting of the Assembly, every Member of the Assembly who spoke said that this Bill was very important and vital to the interest of the people of Singapore. Therefore, I do not wish to be left behind in expressing my dissatisfaction with the method by which this Bill is going to be rushed through without first giving an opportunity to the Opposition to review it thoroughly, because it has been found, as expressed earlier, that the amendments just tabled by the Government clearly show that they are contrary to what the Government claims them to be, that is, the Bill is in the interest of all concerned. We have just been made to understand that the Government has considered these amendments after receiving the views and representations of many trade unions who had offered their views. Hence the Government has tabled many amendments. It cannot be said, however, that only trade unions were given the opportunity to express their views on the Bill which affects industrial relations. Similarly, the Opposition are not satisfied, as they were not given an opportunity. We must not forget that in this Assembly we are not representing the

Column: 226

workers or employers but we are here responsible for the enacting of Bills which give protection to all sections of the community in Singapore, and not merely a certain section. Hence it follows that the views expressed by the Opposition for the postponement of this Bill should receive the attention of the Minister, because we, in the Opposition, will also be held responsible for the enactment of any Bills that are put before this Assembly.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I remember the Prime Minister saying on Wednesday that there was no principle on which the Government could give way. But I do submit, Sir, that the amendments proposed by the Minister for Labour and Law constitute a withdrawal of some of the major principles adumbrated in the Bill. The Minister in his Second Reading did not consider it necessary to inform this House that he had discussions with representatives of the trade unions and representatives of the employers. It was left to a Government back-bencher to disclose it to this House. I do submit that, in future, when matters of importance are involved, the Minister should inform this House of what has been taking place.

    Furthermore, Sir, he has not informed the House in what way the representatives had made objections to him. Sir, if he will be so good as to inform this House, I would like to know the names of the representatives of the trade unions who saw him as well as the names of the representatives of the employers.

    The Chairman: I think perhaps the debate is ranging a bit too far. If the Minister is, in fact, going to disclose these names, I think he would probably be out of order, because we are now debating whether or not proceedings on this Bill should be postponed. The debate must therefore be confined to the reasons why consideration of the Bill should be postponed, and nothing further.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Why I ask for the information is because it is felt by the Opposition that the amendments proposed are as a result of one-sided discussions between the Government and

Column: 227

some of the trade unions. As you have ruled, Sir, we will not be in a position to get the information we want. But I do submit that questions of principle are involved, and that what the Prime Minister told the House last Wednesday, that the Government would not give way on any principle whatsoever, is not borne out by the amendments to be proposed.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, when we debated the Bill two days ago, the nature of the amendments proposed was not known to the Opposition nor, Sir, was it known to the public. We did not realise that the amendments are so vital that they practically change the character of the whole Bill. On that ground, Sir, we believe that the public must be kept informed of later developments so that there can be a test of public reaction.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, when the principle of this Bill was being debated, I remember that in my reply I charged the Opposition Front Bench with showing so very little or no attention to the contents of this very important Bill. Mr Speaker, I did say in my speech when I moved the Second Reading of the Bill that the Explanatory Statement published in the Bill summarises in considerable detail the main provisions of the Bill. I also went on to say that in Committee I would move certain amendments which would not affect the general features of the scheme embodied in the Bill. Those were the exact words I used.

    Mr Speaker, when the Member for Cairnhill was speaking, it appeared to me that he was not informed of the amendments that the Government had sent in, and I interrupted on a point of information and pointed out to the House that the amendments had, in fact, been submitted by the Government.

    Mr Speaker, the Government is also charged with having given no publicity to these amendments. Mr Speaker, I gave an interview to the reporters in the Chinese Press and the Straits Times on Tuesday afternoon, and the main provisions of the amendments which the Government will move were, in fact, published in the Straits Times on Wednesday morning.

Column: 228



    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Members of the Opposition have had ample time to consider the amendments that Government proposes to move this afternoon. In fact, there was a public holiday yesterday and the House was not in session, and if the Member for Cairnhill is the champion of the people, as he wants to make out that he is now, surely he could have spent some time yesterday looking at these amendments. Or if he had not got a copy of the amendments, he could have got one from his learned friend sitting next to him, the Member for Farrer Park. I am horrified to know that he told this House this afternoon that the first time that he had received these amendments was this afternoon at 2.30.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: No, no.

    Mr Byrne: Let him say no. But I always say we speak the truth.

    The Chairman: I think there has been some misunderstanding. I think the Member for Chairnhill said he saw these amendments at 2.30 p.m. on Wednesday.

    Mr Byrne: I beg your pardon, Sir. That means, Mr Speaker, Sir, that he has had ample time to look at these amendments.

    Mr Speaker, I have pointed out repeatedly that the amendments do not in any way affect the main structure of this Bill. For that reason, the Government wishes to proceed with all these amendments this afternoon.

    On the question of my discussions with representatives of employers and representatives of trade unions, I had referred to all these when I replied during the debate on the Second Reading of the Bill. As a result of the discussions that I have had both with the representatives of the unions and the employers, the Government has, after taking into account both representations, drafted the amendments which we hope to move this afternoon, so that it has' not been a one-sided manoeuvre, as the Opposition Front Bench are trying to suggest now.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, since they require a little more time, I do not mind giving them a little more time. We will come back to the Committee stage after item 7 on the Order Paper for today.

Column: 229



    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, there was nothing on the Second Reading of the Bill which the Opposition could have said. The Opposition quite frankly informed the House that they were in complete agreement with the principle involved in the Bill. As the Second Reading is concerned with the debate on the principle of the Bill, there was nothing that the Opposition could say in criticism.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I think it was the Hon. the Prime Minister who said that this was the first attempt made by the Legislature to bring the rule of law into industrial relations where previously the rule of the jungle had prevailed. That, I thought, was an admirable sentiment and something which is very necessary if confidence is to be established which will attract capital to this place and keep it here. If we are going to introduce the rule of law where the rule of the jungle had prevailed, then the Court must be able to enforce its awards both against the employee and the employer. That is the rule of law as I understand it, Mr Speaker. The rule of the jungle, as we all understand it, is where the superior survives and the inferior is destroyed. We want the rule of law. But when we read the amendments, Mr Speaker, Sir, we find that the awards can be enforced against the employer, but it seems that the employees are not so bound. That is our reading of the amendments. If that is correct, then there are no sanctions attached to the failure on the part of the employee to observe an award. If that is the correct interpretation of the amendments, Mr Speaker, where then is the rule of law?

3.00 p.m.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, various Members of the Opposition have based their request for a delay in considering this Bill in Committee on the point that the amendments proposed by the Government have been such as to radically change the nature of the Bill. But none of them have given a single ins-

Column: 230

tance of any way in which the amendments proposed by the Government have made any basic changes to the nature of the Bill. It may be that in the course of celebrations over Thaipusam -

    An hon. Member: Penance!

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: - they might have read into the amendments things not meant to be read into.

    Now, let us not go into a panic over these things. The Bill in its original and in its amended forms sets out the procedures and regulations whereby disputes between unions and employers can be settled in an orderly fashion. That was the aim of the original Bill and that is the aim of the Bill as amended. Again, there is the claim that the amendments have been so drastic as to alter the balance between employers and employees - a balance which the Opposition Members approved in respect of the original Bill, but which they disapprove in respect of the amendments, presumably because they suspect that the amendments have given concessions to the unions but not to employers. This apparently has caused considerable dismay among Members of the Opposition who everyone knows represent vested interests.

    Let us put both our feet firmly on the ground and let us not indulge in flights of fantasies about the effect of these amendments in reverting industrial relations to the rule of the jungle. May I ask the Opposition to remember always that the P.A.P. Government acts with decision? It has not been hasty in drafting the Bill. It has given due consideration to proposals and counter- proposals from the parties affected. But there must be some finality in these things, and if we were to act in the manner which Members of the Opposition want us to, that is, to preserve a fine balance between the groups concerned, we would go on balancing for the next five years. Members of the Opposition may well be reminded of the story of Columbus when he wanted to balance an egg. The best way is to bang

Column: 231

the egg and break one end of it and the rest of the egg stands quite stably in this way.

    Mr Chairman, I have no sympathy whatsoever with the pleas for delay by the Opposition. I think they have completely exaggerated the extent to which the changes proposed have altered the nature of this Bill.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I did not go into the details of the proposed amendments in order to air our stand that the amendments proposed by the Government go a long way to alter the principle of the Bill. I thought that if I had done that you might have ruled me out of order. To suggest -

    The Chairman: Order. I think I probably would have ruled the hon. Member out of order. I would suggest that the way to tackle this particular problem, in so far as the complaint of the Opposition are concerned that the principles of certain clauses have been altered, is to raise the point when we come to the particular clause and then move that consideration of the clause itself be postponed. If that meets with the Opposition's wishes, perhaps we can proceed.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: May I proceed, Sir?

    The Chairman: Yes, Tun Lim Yew Hock.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: With respect, Sir, it was because you have allowed the Hon, the Minister to say that we had given no valid reason. I was trying to say why we could not.

    The Chairman: Order. I appreciate that and I think the House does appreciate that. There must be some valid reasons in the minds of the Opposition why they think that the principles have been departed from. Probably the Minister for Finance knew that and said what he did say with his tongue in his cheek. But I am just trying to direct the Members of this Assembly on a speedier course. It

Column: 232

seems to me that we are debating round in circles. Perhaps if some agreement can be reached on the lines I have proposed, we can proceed.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, we had hoped that the Committee stage of this Bill could be postponed to a later stage whereby the public would have at least considered the major amendments proposed by the Government. The Minister for Labour and Law has suggested that if we had qualms about the amendments he might agree to taking the Committee stage when all the other business of the day has been disposed of. May I respectfully submit, Sir, that such a suggestion is nothing but frivolous?

    The Chairman: Order. I think I have ruled the word "frivolous" out of order. Will the Member please withdraw?

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: I withdraw, Sir. I will therefore say that such a suggestion is not in keeping with the dignity of this House.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, when I suggested just now that the Committee stage of this Bill be taken after item No. 5 on the Order Paper, I did so because I mistakenly believed that the Member for Cairnhill had said that the first time that he had seen these amendments was at 2.30 this afternoon. As a matter of fact, it was pointed out to me that he had seen these amendments at 2.30 on Wednesday afternoon. This has made the case for an application for an adjournment even more - I am very much tempted to use the same word, Sir.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the principle of the Bill was carefully gone into when the Second Reading was debated last Wednesday. When replying, I remember I pointed out where the amendments departed from the main provisions of the Bill. I remember informing this House that the Government had, after discussions with the unions, agreed to

Column: 233

take out the provisions in the Bill dealing with the de-registration of unions. I remember informing the House that the Government had, after discussions with the unions, decided that the provisions restricting the activities of union leaders, when they were found guilty of contempt of court, were to be preserved. I remember dealing with all these matters, and I am very surprised that the Member for Farrer Park has got so lost in the jungle of his thoughts that he should have suddenly accused the Government of wanting to introduce the law of the jungle in industrial relations. If he had been a little more careful and given more thought to what I had said when replying to the debate on the Second Reading, then he would not have made that very unfair remark.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, concerning the remark that we could have spent a few hours yesterday studying the amendments; I would like to say this. It is because we have studied them thoroughly that we now feel, not for our sake, but for the sake of the public, that the public need to be informed of these amendments, and they need to give thought to them. This is why we are proposing a postponement of the Committee stage. It is not for ourselves. We spent the whole day yesterday discussing them.

    The Chairman: I take it that the suggestion by the Government that the Committee stage be taken after item 7 on the Order Paper is not acceptable to the Opposition. I shall then put the Question on the motion, and the Government side will no doubt vote in the way they think appropriate.

    The Chairman: Before we proceed, I wish to draw the attention of the Opposition Members to Standing Order 71 (7) which reads:

    "A clause may be postponed, unless a decision has already been taken upon an amendment thereto...".

Therefore, if any Opposition Member wishes to move that a clause be postponed he or she should do so before an amendment is moved or considered.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    *In page 2, lines 13 to 15, to leave out "or of any department of Her Majesty's Government in the United Kingdom functioning within Singapore".
* See column 234.


    Mr Speaker, Sir, when moving the Second Reading of this Bill, I explained why Government has thought it necessary that the Services and their employees should be left out of the provisions of this Bill and I do not propose to repeat what I have already said.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Opposition would indeed be grateful to the Minister if he would repeat the reasons which he gave during the Second Reading of the Bill. Sir, the reason I ask is that we do not have a copy of the Hansard.

    Mr Byrne: Sir, that proves my point earlier on when I said that the Opposition Members gave very little attention either to -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: On a point of order, Sir. Is it out of order for a Member of the Opposition to ask for information?

    The Chairman: It is not a point of order. No point of order has arisen.

    Mr Byrne: If I am not mistaken. I think the Member for Cairnhill has asked me to repeat what I said when I moved the Second Reading of the Bill. My point is that if he had paid attention to what I was saying, then there would have been no need for his asking me to repeat what I then said. In order that he may he informed, I shall now proceed to restate what I then said on the Second Reading of the Bill:

    "... we have also decided to leave the Services and their employees out of the provisions of this Bill. This is because our State is fully self-governing in internal affairs but is not a sovereign State as far as external relations and internal security are concerned. For that reason, we are in no position to pass any local legislation binding on Her Majesty's Government. That being so, we consider that it would be advisable to leave it to the Services and their employees to decide whether they would freely wish to avail themselves of the machinery we have provided in this Bill for the settlement of industrial disputes, and it would be up to them therefore to decide whether they would freely come in or keep out altogether."

Column: 236

I also said then, Mr Speaker:

    "In this connection, I have been advised by the United Kingdom Commissioner in Singapore, with whom both the Prime Minister and I have had discussions, that the United Kingdom departments are not opposed in principle to the objects of the Bill, since indeed arbitration courts have for long been a normal feature of civil service negotiating machinery in the United Kingdom."

I also informed the House:

    "I have also been informed by the United Kingdom Commission here that the United Kingdom departments could not, however, agree to the Bill's application without modification to cover certain aspects which are governed by United Kingdom statute or practice and are not within the direct competence of the United Kingdom Service departments functioning in Singapore."

I also expressed the hope that:
